overview_of_class:
The Practicum seminar in adaptation for first-year students in the Theatre MFA Directing Program meets once a week for three hours. The seminar addresses four topic areas.
(1) Principles of storytelling for stage adaptations of non-dramatic texts.
(2) Narrators onstage: models for the dynamic interaction of storytelling and dramatic representation.
(3) Pretext analysis: the place of appropriation, allegory, and mash-up in stage adaptation.
(4) Imagining the performance space for plays with narrators.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Three. Receive permission number directly from Paul Edwards at edwdoyle@northwestern.edu or edwdoyle1@gmail.com

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
(1) Four presentations in seminar meetings across the quarter (one every two-three weeks) responding to specific assignments.
(2) One end-of-quarter process paper describing the seminar member's quarter-long progress on an original stage adaptation of a non-dramatic text.
(3) Note: the Practicum seminar no longer requires a staging project with members of a separate undergraduate adaptation class. All presentations will happen in once-a-week, three-hour seminar meetings.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
(1) Non-dramatic texts (short stories, selections from novels, compilations of narrative non-fiction) suggested by the seminar members for quarter-long adaptation projects. Source texts will be posted by the instructor to the NU Canvas course site.
(2) Required and recommended readings (essays and book chapters) posted by the instructor to the NU Canvas course site.
